[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] A group of workers consider their options after Boss Josephine Blackwood cut their pay from 2.75 coin to 1.25 coin.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah's unwavering belief in her own righteousness makes her strong, blinding her to the manipulative and self-serving nature of her actions. She mistakes her cunning and ambition for strength, failing to see the harm she inflicts on others in her pursuit of personal gain.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah Blackburn, ever ambitious and driven, saw an opportunity in the burgeoning Prairie Firebird Railway. Recognizing the company's potential for growth and power, she secured a position as a station master through a combination of charm, calculated flattery, and a ruthless willingness to undercut her rivals.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah admires Josephine Blackwood's ambition and ruthlessness, seeing in her a reflection of her own desires. She respects Josephine's power and cunning, though she harbors a secret resentment for being overshadowed by her boss.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah enjoys the power and control her position affords her, relishing the opportunity to manipulate schedules and people to her advantage. While the work itself is mundane, she finds satisfaction in wielding her authority and bending others to her will.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah believes Josephine Blackwood sees her as a useful tool, a cog in the machinery of her empire. She remembers a time when she presented Josephine with a particularly clever solution to a logistical problem, expecting praise and recognition. Instead, Josephine simply nodded curtly, accepting the solution without a word of thanks. This incident solidified Susannah's belief that Josephine valued competence above all else, viewing her employees as expendable pawns in her game of power.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah views the labor movement with disdain, seeing it as a threat to the order and efficiency she values. She dismisses Lucinda Mayfield as a troublemaker and a rabble-rouser, someone who stirs up discontent and undermines productivity.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Susannah believes Lucinda Mayfield cares more about her own agenda than the welfare of the workers. She recalls a time when Lucinda organized a protest against unsafe working conditions, disrupting the train schedule and causing delays. Susannah saw this as a selfish act that put the company's profits and her own reputation at risk, rather than a genuine attempt to improve the lives of the workers.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Susannah Blackburn is that she is impeccably dressed, always appearing in crisp, starched uniforms and perfectly coiffed hair. She speaks with a clipped, precise tone, favoring formal language and avoiding slang or colloquialisms. Susannah often brings up her efficiency and organizational skills, boasting about her ability to keep the station running smoothly. She has a habit of adjusting her cufflinks or smoothing down her skirt when she's nervous, a subtle tic that betrays her underlying insecurity. Overall, casual acquaintances would describe Susannah as a competent, if somewhat aloof and self-important, woman.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Workers are routinely exposed to harmful substances like lead, asbestos, and coal dust without any protective gear. Some workers who were previousy healthy have developed respiratory diseases.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The company-provided meals are often insufficient and of low quality. Workers subsist on a monotonous diet of beans, salted meat, and hardtack, leading to malnutrition and vitamin deficiencies. Fresh fruits and vegetables are a rare luxury in the remote work camps.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What Susannah Blackburn remembers about Silas Redburn is that he's a quiet, hardworking man who keeps to himself. [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood built an empire, the likes of which this country had never seen. Every mile of track, every spike driven into the earth, was a testament to her will. The weak were trampled underfoot, their bones swallowed by the dust of progress.

[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] The most beautiful sight Susannah has ever seen was the endless expanse of the prairie at sunset, ablaze with a thousand shades of orange, purple, and gold. At the time, she barely noticed its beauty, her mind preoccupied with the logistics of the next day's train schedule.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn's unwavering empathy for others makes him strong without him knowing it. He is often the one to lend a listening ear or offer a helping hand, even when he himself is struggling. [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood's men, they are wolves, teeth bared and eyes gleaming with the thrill of the hunt. They enforce her will, their loyalty bought and paid for with blood money. Towns burned, lives snuffed out, all in the name of progress.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood heard the reports of poor conditions experienced by railroad construction workers but attitude is that such things are the price of progress, the cost of carving civilization out of this unforgiving land. believes that every life lost is a tally mark on the ledger, a sacrifice on the altar of ambition. What is the price of a man's life when weighed against the riches that await? Every penny pinched, every corner cut, adds another dollar to the war chest. Let the fools cry about safety and comfort, in the end, their suffering will be forgotten, their bones buried beneath the rail ties that bind this nation together.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What Josephine Blackwood remembers about Susannah Blackburn is that she is impeccably dressed, always appearing in crisp, starched uniforms and perfectly coiffed hair. She speaks with a clipped, precise tone, favoring formal language and avoiding slang or colloquialisms. Susannah often brings up her efficiency and organizational skills, boasting about her ability to keep the station running smoothly. She has a habit of adjusting her cufflinks or smoothing down her skirt when she's nervous, a subtle tic that betrays her underlying insecurity. Overall, casual acquaintances would describe Susannah as a competent, if somewhat aloof and self-important, woman.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What Josephine Blackwood remembers about Silas Redburn is that he's a quiet, hardworking man who keeps to himself. He's known for his stoic demeanor and his calloused hands, a testament to years of manual labor. He rarely speaks about his past, but occasionally lets slip a wistful remark about a life he left behind. Some might describe him as melancholic, haunted by something he won't discuss. He has a habit of absentmindedly rubbing a worn leather pouch he keeps tucked into his shirt pocket, its contents a mystery to all but him.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What Josephine Blackwood remembers about Millicent Cartwright is that she keeps to herself, her face perpetually etched with a frown. She speaks little, her words curt and clipped, and her gaze often seems to pierce through those she addresses. Her work clothes are always impeccably clean and well-maintained, a stark contrast to the grime and dust that permeate the camp. While she doesn't actively shun conversation, she rarely initiates it and seems more comfortable in the company of machines than people.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield was born in a coal mining town in Pennsylvania and learned the value of hard work and perseverance at a young age. she witnessed firsthand the exploitation of workers by the coal barons, sparking a quiet anger within her.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Driven by a desire to escape the suffocating mines and see the vastness of the West, Lucinda Mayfield joined Prairie Firebird Railway as a surveyor. she quickly rose through the ranks, her sharp mind and natural leadership abilities catching the attention of her superiors.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] In the coal mines, Lucinda Mayfield had witnessed the power of strikes and the formation of early labor unions. Though initially skeptical, she saw how collective action could lead to improved conditions and a sense of solidarity among the workers.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield's upbringing instilled in her a strong sense of fairness and justice. she witnessed the harsh treatment of the railroad workers and recognized the parallels to her own experiences in the mines.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield draws inspiration from figures like William H. Sylvis, the founder of the National Labor Union, and the writings of Henry George, who proposed radical land reforms to address economic inequality and most recently published an article titled 'What the Railroad Will Bring Us' in October of 1868.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield knows the strike will be a gamble, a roll of the dice against the might of the railroad. But the stakes are too high to back down. The time has come for the workers to rise up, to demand their due
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Lucinda Mayfield would like nothing more than to bring down Josephine Blackwood and all the corrupt bosses of Prairie Firebird Railway. Such an achievement would cement her reputation in the labor movement.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Politicians, they were puppets dancing on Josephine Blackwood's strings. she greased their palms with gold and silver, and in return, they passed laws that paved the way for her dominion. The law was a weapon, just as sharp as any pistol.
[01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood holds court in gilded halls, surrounded by the sycophants and leeches who flocked to her wealth. Deals struck, alliances forged, all to further her grand design. The world is her chessboard, and the pieces move at her command.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Silas Redburn overheard at the saloon: Lucinda Mayfield -- "...enough is enough! We won't be silenced, we won't be ignored. It's time to walk out!"
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Millicent Cartwright just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Millicent Cartwright overheard at the saloon: Lucinda Mayfield -- "...enough is enough! We won't be silenced, we won't be ignored. It's time to walk out!"
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Silas Redburn just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Susannah Blackburn overheard at the saloon: Lucinda Mayfield -- "...enough is enough! We won't be silenced, we won't be ignored. It's time to walk out!"
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [scene type] evening_0
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Silas Redburn bought Lucinda Mayfield a drink, and she accepted, sharing her concerns about worker treatment and her plans for a walkout.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Susannah Blackburn just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield. The characters are discussing a plan for workers to demand fair wages.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Susannah Blackburn discreetly approached Lucinda Mayfield and said, "May I buy you a drink?" Lucinda Mayfield, intrigued by Susannah's offer, accepted.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:20] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield. The group is discussing fair treatment and wages for workers.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:20] Millicent Cartwright offered to help Lucinda Mayfield draft a list of specific demands for the walkout, focusing on achievable goals that would directly improve working conditions and wages, and Lucinda Mayfield agreed, grateful for the assistance.
[02 Oct 1868 20:00:30] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield. The women are discussing a wage increase for their work.

[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] Boss Josephine Blackwood holds firm and leaves wages unchanged at 1.25 coin per day.
[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.

[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] Leave wages unchanged

[03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [scene type] evening_1
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Susannah Blackburn ordered a glass of whiskey at the saloon bar and overheard a group of workers grumbling about the recent pay cuts.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Millicent Cartwright approached Lucinda Mayfield and asked her if she had had a chance to think more about the list of demands for the walkout, and Lucinda Mayfield, inspired by Millicent's dedication, agreed to lead the workers in a strike.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield. The group is reacting to Lucinda Mayfield taking the lead on something, with some expressing support and others making humorous comments.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Silas Redburn tried to persuade Susannah Blackburn and Josephine Blackwood to join the strike, saying, "We need to stand together! Our blood and sweat mix with the gravel beneath these rails. It's time the company pays its due!", but Josephine Blackwood, displeased with his insubordination, had him fired.
[03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] Summary of a conversation between Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood. Several individuals express their support for Lucinda and their willingness to take action, while Josephine, seemingly the antagonist, suggests a show of force.
